20.text: Creek Group dominate the area. Amphibolitic units are generally fine grained, strongly foliated

21.text: and hornblende-rich. The BIF is finely laminated and commonly folded.

24.text: sequence.  These  porphyry  bodies  commonly  have  sheared  margins  with  quartz-sulphide

27.text: dyke cutting through the City of Melbourne area which post-dates mineralisation.

text:
later events have produced regional folding with localized extension. 
 3.2  Local Geology 
 The City of Melbourne Project area is located along the western edge of a north-south striking, 
 eastern limb of a regional scale antiform. Amphibolites and quartz-magnetite BIF of the Luke 
 Creek Group dominate the area. Amphibolitic units are generally fine grained, strongly foliated 
 and hornblende-rich. The BIF is finely laminated and commonly folded. 
 A suite of NW trending quartz-feldspar porphyry dykes and stocks intrude the BIF-Amphibolite 
 sequence.  These  porphyry  bodies  commonly  have  sheared  margins  with  quartz-sulphide 
 veining  parallel  to  the  shear  fabric.  These  deformed  porphyries  are  commonly  mineralized, 
 suggesting a late age for the mineralizing event.  There is also a north-easdt trending dolerite 
 dyke cutting through the City of Melbourne area which post-dates mineralisation. 
 Gold  mineralisation  at  the  City  of  Melbourne  deposit  is  hosted  within  a  0.3  to  1.0m  wide 
 sheeted quartz vein (known as the ‘Main Vein’), that strikes at 015o, and dips at 30-40o to the 
 west.  Alteration  along  selvedge  zones  consists  of  chlorite-epidote-sericite-garnet-carbonate 
 with 2-3% fine grained disseminated sulphide, mainly pyrite with lesser chalcopyrite.  Historical 
 sampling also indicates that another auriferous 0.1-0.4m wide quartz vein is located 0.1-0.3m 
 above  the  ‘Main  Vein’.  The  selvedge  zone  between  the  two  vein  sets  is  also  weakly 
 mineralized.

18.text: Prosperity Resources compiled and digitised all available historical data, as well as prioritising

19.text: targets within the tenement utilising detailed aeromagnetics and Landsat TM.  A few rock chip

20.text: samples were also collected which returned gold assay values of up to 9.5 g/t.

24.text: Six  vertical  RC  holes  were  drilled  during  February  and  March,  2004  (A  total  of  358m  was

25.text: drilled, with individual hole depths ranging between 40m and 80m.  The drilling was aimed at

26.text: determining the strike, dip and extent of the ‘Main Vein’, and to verify if the intrusive dolerite

27.text: dyke  terminated  mineralisation.      This  drilling  successfully  extended  and  further  defined  the

28.text: known mineralisation at the City of Melbourne deposit.  The dolerite dyke does not terminate

29.text: the mineralisation as was previously thought.

 4.2.1  October 2002 to October 2003 
 Prosperity Resources compiled and digitised all available historical data, as well as prioritising 
 targets within the tenement utilising detailed aeromagnetics and Landsat TM.  A few rock chip 
 samples were also collected which returned gold assay values of up to 9.5 g/t.      
 4.2.2  October 2003 to October 2004 
 Six  vertical  RC  holes  were  drilled  during  February  and  March,  2004  (A  total  of  358m  was 
 drilled, with individual hole depths ranging between 40m and 80m.  The drilling was aimed at 
 determining the strike, dip and extent of the ‘Main Vein’, and to verify if the intrusive dolerite 
 dyke  terminated  mineralisation.      This  drilling  successfully  extended  and  further  defined  the 
 known mineralisation at the City of Melbourne deposit.  The dolerite dyke does not terminate 
 the mineralisation as was previously thought.

text:
4.2.3  October 2004 to October 2005 
 One  diamond  drill  hole  was  completed  at  the  City  of  Melbourne  prospect.    This  hole  was 
 planned to intersect the mineralised quartz vein in order to further characterise mineralisation 
 and to gain some geotechnical knowledge of the ore zone.  The geology log is presented as 
 The geology in the drill hole was dominated by a mafic rock that varied in grain size from fine to 
 coarse (basalt to gabbro).  There was an interpreted mineralised zone from 46.8m → 53.25m 
 that showed brecciation of the host rock, epidote and potassic rich (pink) feldspar alteration and 
 quartz  veining  that  ranged  in  scale  from  mm  to  cm  wide.    There  was  up  to  2%  sulphides 
 present in the host – pyrite and chalcopyrite.  
 There were three distinct quartz veins intersected within the mineralised zone:  
 •  47.25m → 47.4m - 15cm wide 
 •  48.0m → 48.3m – 30cm wide 
 •  52.7m → 52.96m – 25cm wide 
 The  gold  results  from  PD001  were  lower  than  expected.  This  is  thought  to  be  due  to  the 
 nuggetty nature of the gold in this area.
